body.p:
We read with great interest the article by Zheng et al (2025) titled ” An artificial intelligence model for nuclear grading of clear cell renal cell carcinoma using whole slide images: a retrospective, multicentre, diagnostic study “ published in the International Journal of Surgery[1]. The development of the RIGDAS system signifies a substantial advancement in the realm of artificial intelligence-assisted pathology, with promising implications for enhancing clinical efficiency and diagnostic accuracy. Nevertheless, it is imperative to underscore several methodological concerns that have the potential to influence the interpretation of the results and the model’s generalizability. Transparency In the reporting of Artificial Intelligence-The TITAN guideline[2].
1. Statistical Anomalies in Performance Metrics

The reported AUC values in the external validation cohorts (e.g., 0.980 [0.960–1.989] for the training set) include an upper confidence interval limit exceeding the maximum possible AUC of 1.0 (Table 2, Fig. 5A). This suggests potential errors in confidence interval calculation or data processing. While the model’s high AUC is commendable, such anomalies necessitate clarification to ensure statistical rigor.
2. Inconsistencies in Sample Size Reporting

The manuscript states that 5697 slides from 1807 patients were collected initially (Abstract), but after quality control, only 5525 slides from 1699 patients were utilized (Results). The discrepancy of 108 excluded patients is not accounted for in the flow diagram (Fig. 1) or baseline characteristics (Table 1). Transparency in exclusions is critical for reproducibility.
3. Ethical Considerations for Public Datasets

The study uses public cohorts (TCGA-KIRC, CPTAC) without clarifying whether these datasets were re-reviewed by the study’s pathologists for ISUP grading consistency. Public datasets often lack standardized grading protocols, and direct adoption of their original labels may introduce heterogeneity. This conflict with the study’s emphasis on centralized expert consensus (Methods: “reference standards determined by two senior pathologists”).
4. Methodological Ambiguity in WSI-Level Aggregation

RIGDAS processes multiple WSIs per patient but does not specify how slide-level predictions (e.g., 256 × 256-pixel patches) are aggregated into patient-level grades. This is clinically relevant, as tumors exhibit heterogeneity. The description in Fig. 2 (“WSI-level predictions”) lacks technical detail, risking reproducibility.
5. Limitations in Clinical Validation

The human-AI collaboration study reported a 100% correction rate for senior pathologists using RIGDAS (e.g., 12/12 misclassifications corrected for Pathologist C). Such perfection is atypical in diagnostic studies and may reflect selection bias in the 80-patient subset. Broader validation is needed to confirm these gains.

sec.title: Concluding remarks
sec.p:
This seminal study establishes RIGDAS as a transformative artificial intelligence (AI) tool for standardized renal cell carcinoma grading. The study’s pioneering strengths lie in three key areas: (1) the successful validation across multi-scanner, multi-center cohorts—a critical advancement rarely achieved in computational pathology; (2) the demonstration of significant diagnostic rescue in pathologist-AI collaboration (100% error correction for senior pathologists); and (3) the provision of biologically interpretable heatmaps linking nuclear features to International System for Urogenital Pathology (ISUP) grades. These innovations hold the potential to reduce inter-institutional grading variability, thereby contributing to the enhancement of global diagnostic standards. In order to refine clinical integration, the following recommendations are proposed:
The implementation of scanner-agnostic robustness tests, employing the use of adversarial patches as a means to assess vulnerabilities in real-world settings, is imperative.
The objective of this study is to validate the aggregation algorithm for WSI-level predictions in multi-focal tumors.
The present study will explore the influence of confounder variables, such as necrosis and artifacts, on model certainty.
Addressing these nuances has the potential to amplify the impact of this exceptional work, which represents a paradigm shift toward precision pathology powered by artificial intelligence.

sec.title: Ethical approval
sec.p: This study did not involve patients or procedures requiring ethical approval. All data utilized were derived from publicly available sources/literature reviews and did not pertain to individual privacy. Thus, ethical approval was not applicable.

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: As this study did not involve patients or volunteers, informed consent was not required. No personal details or images of individuals were utilized in the research.
